title: 109_hr4524
content: The "Congressional Pension Forfeiture Act of 2005" states that Members of Congress who breach the public trust should forfeit their retirement benefits, as taxpayers should not bear the cost for such actions. The "Congressional Pension Forfeiture Act of 2005" mandates that Members of Congress convicted of specific offenses while in office will not have their service counted for retirement benefits under the Civil Service Retirement System. They are entitled to receive their lump-sum credit for the service not considered. The "Congressional Pension Forfeiture Act of 2005" stipulates that Members of Congress convicted of certain offenses related to their service during the One Hundred Tenth Congress or later will forfeit their retirement benefits under the Civil Service Retirement System. The specified offenses include bribery, conspiracy to defraud the Government, and false claims. The curr_chunk discusses various offenses under title 18 and the Internal Revenue Code that can lead to penalties, including perjury. The curr_chunk discusses penalties for individuals convicted of offenses related to false denial and subornation of perjury. It also mentions regulations to be prescribed by the Office to carry out this subsection. The curr_chunk amends Section 8411 of title 5, United States Code, stating that the service of an individual convicted of certain offenses shall not be taken into account for retirement benefits. The individual will be entitled to their lump-sum credit attributable to the excluded service. The amendment to Section 8411 of title 5, United States Code, specifies that individuals convicted of certain offenses during their service as a Member of Congress will be ineligible for retirement benefits under this chapter. The Office will establish regulations for implementation, including provisions for interest on any lump-sum credit. The amendment also includes provisions for interest on lump-sum payments and restrictions on denying benefits authorized by statute. Contributions made by the Government under the Thrift Savings Plan for an individual's benefit may be forfeited under certain circumstances. Individuals convicted of certain offenses during their service as a Member of Congress may forfeit contributions and earnings from the Thrift Savings Plan.
